articles.headline: Obama Commutes Sentences for 8 in Crack Cocaine Cases
articles.snippet: President Obama said the inmates, each of whom has been imprisoned for at least 15 years, had been sentenced under what is now recognized as an “unfair system.”
articles.abstract: President Obama said the inmates, each of whom has been imprisoned for at least 15 years, had been sentenced under what is now recognized as an “unfair system.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, expanding his push to curtail severe penalties in drug cases, on Thursday commuted the sentences of eight federal inmates who were convicted of crack cocaine offenses. Each inmate has been imprisoned for at least 15 years, and six were sentenced to life in prison.

articles.headline: Loophole Slowly Tightens on a Bank
articles.snippet: It wasn’t bad loans that created big losses for Zions Bankcorporation, it was ill-fated and ill-timed financial innovation.
articles.abstract: It wasn’t bad loans that created big losses for Zions Bankcorporation, it was ill-fated and ill-timed financial innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Oh what a tangled web we weave, when first we practice to deceive.”

articles.headline: An Easing of Rules on Charges by Amex
articles.snippet: Agreements with American Express, MasterCard and Visa have cleared the way for vendors to institute what is essentially two-tier pricing for shoppers.
articles.abstract: Agreements with American Express, MasterCard and Visa have cleared the way for vendors to institute what is essentially two-tier pricing for shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a decade of legal battles, the three major credit card companies are backing away from longstanding policies that prevented merchants from charging customers extra for paying with plastic.

articles.headline: Fans Criticize Move to Suspend ‘Duck Dynasty’ Star
articles.snippet: Religious and conservative groups accused A&E of attacking Christian values and free speech after the network suspended Phil Robertson over comments he made in GQ magazine.
articles.abstract: Religious and conservative groups accused A&E of attacking Christian values and free speech after the network suspended Phil Robertson over comments he made in GQ magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The A&E network was assailed on Thursday by thousands of fans of its most popular show over its decision to suspend the patriarch of the “Duck Dynasty” family, Phil Robertson, because of comments made in an interview in GQ magazine that the network deemed homophobic.

articles.headline: Growing Corruption Inquiry Hits Close to Turkish Leader
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan weathered a summer of protest, but a corruption scandal poses a greater challenge.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan weathered a summer of protest, but a corruption scandal poses a greater challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In building his political career, Turkey’s powerful and charismatic prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, relied heavily on the support of a Sufi mystic preacher whose base of operations is now in Pennsylvania.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Sebnem Arsu and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Investors’ Story Left Out of Wall St. ‘Wolf’ Movie
articles.snippet: Left untold in a film about the penny-stock swindler Jordan Belfort and his firm, Stratton Oakmont, are the stories of the investors.
articles.abstract: Left untold in a film about the penny-stock swindler Jordan Belfort and his firm, Stratton Oakmont, are the stories of the investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wolf of Wall Street is about to have his day.

articles.headline: Another Rule in Health Law Is Scaled Back
articles.snippet: Millions facing the cancellation of health insurance policies will be exempt from penalties if they go without next year, the White House said.
articles.abstract: Millions facing the cancellation of health insurance policies will be exempt from penalties if they go without next year, the White House said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Millions of people facing the cancellation of health insurance policies will be allowed to buy catastrophic coverage and will be exempt from penalties if they go without insurance next year, the White House said Thursday night.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Tension as It Examined Mortgage Cases
articles.snippet: The reasoning behind the decisions and the contentious way they divided camps within the agency illuminates how difficult choices are made inside the regulator.
articles.abstract: The reasoning behind the decisions and the contentious way they divided camps within the agency illuminates how difficult choices are made inside the regulator.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s top regulator, sifting through the wreckage of the mortgage crisis, was weighing enforcement actions last year against several large financial companies.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

articles.headline: BlackBerry Staggers to a Deeper, $4.4 Billion Loss
articles.snippet: Revenue dropped 56 percent in the latest quarter as its business continued to shrink. The company also said it would enter a partnership with the Asian manufacturer Foxconn.
articles.abstract: Revenue dropped 56 percent in the latest quarter as its business continued to shrink. The company also said it would enter a partnership with the Asian manufacturer Foxconn.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — BlackBerry, the hobbled smartphone maker, reported more dire financial news on Friday, posting a $4.4 billion loss and a 56 percent drop in revenue in its latest quarter. The company also outlined a sharp retreat from its once-core handset business by entering a partnership with the Asian contract manufacturer Foxconn.

articles.headline: Revision Shows U.S. Growing at Fastest Rate Since 2011
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department revised its estimate of third-quarter growth to 4.1 percent from 3.6 percent, saying consumer and business spending were stronger than originally thought.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department revised its estimate of third-quarter growth to 4.1 percent from 3.6 percent, saying consumer and business spending were stronger than originally thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States economy grew at a surprisingly robust 4.1 percent annual pace in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said on Friday. It was the strongest advance in nearly two years and only the third time the economy had expanded that quickly from one quarter to the next since 2006.

articles.headline: N.S.A. Spied on Allies, Aid Groups and Businesses
articles.snippet: Secret documents reveal more than 1,000 targets of U.S. and British surveillance in recent years, including the office of an Israeli prime minister and heads of international aid organizations.
articles.abstract: Secret documents reveal more than 1,000 targets of U.S. and British surveillance in recent years, including the office of an Israeli prime minister and heads of international aid organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secret documents reveal more than 1,000 targets of American and British surveillance in recent years, including the office of an Israeli prime minister, heads of international aid organizations, foreign energy companies and a European Union official involved in antitrust battles with American technology businesses.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Andrew W. Lehren
